title: RFK Jr.โs MAHA wants to make chemtrail conspiracy theories great again
summary: It's unclear if Kennedy will follow through, but he supports the conspiracy theory.
body: A prominent voice in the Make America Healthy Again movement is pushing for health secretary and anti-vaccine activist Robert F. Kennedy Jr. to make the topic of chemtrail conspiracy theories a federal priority, according to a report by KFF News. KFF obtained a memo , written by MAHA influencer Gray Delany in July, presenting the topic to Calley Means, a White House health advisor. The memo lays out a series of unsubstantiated and far-fetched claims that academic researchers and federal agencies are secretively spreading toxic substances from airplanes, poisoning Americans and spurring large-scale weather events, such as the devastating flooding in Texas last summer. โIt is unconscionable that anyone should be allowed to spray known neurotoxins and environmental toxins over our nationโs citizens, their land, food and water supplies,โ Delany writes in the memo. title: AI-powered features begin creeping deeper into the bedrock of Windows 11
summary: Copilot expands with an emphasis on creating and editing files, voice input.
body: Like virtually every major Windows announcement in the last three years, the spate of features that Microsoft announced for the operating system today all revolve around generative AI. In particular, theyโre concerned with the companyโs more recent preoccupation with โagenticโ AI, an industry buzzword for โtelling AI-powered software to perform a task, which it then does in the background while you move on to other things.โ But the overarching impression I got, both from reading the announcement and sitting through a press briefing earlier this month, is that Microsoft is using language models and other generative AI technologies to try again with Cortana, Microsoftโs failed and discontinued entry in the voice assistant wars of the 2010s. According to Microsoftโs Consumer Chief Marketing Officer Yusuf Mehdi, โAI PCsโ should be able to recognize input โnaturally, in text or voice,โ to be able to guide users based on whatโs on their screens at any given moment, and that AI assistants โshould be able to take action on your behalf.โ Read full article Comments

title: Nation-state hackers deliver malware from โbulletproofโ blockchains
summary: Malicious payloads stored on Ethereum and BNB blockchains are immune to takedowns.
body: Hacking groupsโat least one of which works on behalf of the North Korean governmentโhave found a new and inexpensive way to distribute malware from โbulletproofโ hosts: stashing them on public cryptocurrency blockchains. In a Thursday post , members of the Google Threat Intelligence Group said the technique provides the hackers with their own โbulletproofโ host, a term that describes cloud platforms that are largely immune from takedowns by law enforcement and pressure from security researchers. More traditionally, these hosts are located in countries without treaties agreeing to enforce criminal laws from the US and other nations. These services often charge hefty sums and cater to criminals spreading malware or peddling child sexual abuse material and wares sold in crime-based flea markets. Next-gen, DIY hosting that canโt be tampered with Since February, Google researchers have observed two groups turning to a newer technique to infect targets with credential stealers and other forms of malware. The method, known as EtherHiding, embeds the malware in smart contracts, which are essentially apps that reside on blockchains for Ethereum and other cryptocurrencies. Two or more partiโฆ

title: Ars Live recap: Is the AI bubble about to pop? Ed Zitron weighs in.

body: On Tuesday of last week, Ars Technica hosted a live conversation with Ed Zitron, host of the Better Offline podcast and one of techโs most vocal AI critics, to discuss whether the generative AI industry is experiencing a bubble and when it might burst. My Internet connection had other plans, though, dropping out multiple times and forcing Ars Technicaโs Lee Hutchinson to jump in as an excellent emergency backup host. During the times my connection cooperated, Zitron and I covered OpenAIโs financial issues, lofty infrastructure promises, and why the AI hype machine keeps rolling despite some arguably shaky economics underneath. Leeโs probing questions about per-user costs revealed a potential flaw in AI subscription models: Companies canโt predict whether a user will cost them $2 or $10,000 per month. body: OnePlus is expected to take the wraps off the OnePlus 15 in the next few weeks, but before that, itโs giving us a look at the software that will run on it. OxygenOS 16, which is based on Android 16, will also come to the companyโs other supported phones, and itโs going to include a heaping helping of AI features. OnePlus was slower than most smartphone makers to embrace AI, but itโs full-steam ahead now with new Gemini integrations. OxygenOS 16 is described by OnePlus in grandiose terms as โa defiant rebellion for authenticity.โ In the real world, this update is doing a lot of the same things as other AI-heavy smartphones. Itโs not all AIโOnePlus notes that OxygenOS 16 will include revamped animations that have been carefully designed for smoothness, as well as the O+ remote app that gives you remote access to Windows and Mac PCs. The lock screen is also more customizable, borrowing a page from the likes of Apple and Samsung. OnePlus began embracing AI in June, when it launched a feature called Mind Space on the OnePlus 13S. title: Sony tells SCOTUS that people accused of piracy arenโt โinnocent grandmothersโ
summary: Music companies want ISPs to terminate repeat infringers or pay big damages.
body: Record labels Sony, Warner, and Universal yesterday asked the Supreme Court to help it boot pirates off the Internet. Sony and the other labels filed their brief in Cox Communications v. Sony Music Entertainment , a case involving the cable Internet service provider that rebuffed labelsโ demands for mass terminations of broadband subscribers accused of repeat copyright infringement. The Supreme Courtโs eventual decision in the case may determine whether Internet service providers must terminate the accounts of alleged pirates in order to avoid massive financial liability. Cox has argued that copyright-infringement noticesโwhich are generated by bots and flag users based on their IP addressesโsent by record labels are unreliable. Cox said ISPs canโt verify whether the notices are accurate and that terminating an account would punish every user in a household where only one person may have illegally downloaded copyrighted files. title: Open source GZDoom community splinters after creator inserts AI-generated code
summary: UZDoom fork promises to fix other top-down leadership problems with the decades-old mod.
body: If youโve even idly checked in on the robust world of Doom fan development in recent years, youโve probably encountered one of the hundreds of gameplay mods , WAD files , or entire commercial games based on GZDoom . The open source Doom port โwhich can trace its lineage back to the original launch of ZDoom back in 1998 โadds modern graphics rendering, quality-of-life additions, and incredibly deep modding features to the original Doom source code that John Carmack released in 1997. Now, though, the community behind GZDoom is publicly fracturing, with a large contingent of developers uniting behind a new fork called UZDoom . The move is in apparent protest of the leadership of GZDoom creator and maintainer Cristoph Oelckers (aka Graf Zahl) , who recently admitted to inserting untested AI-generated code into the GZDoom codebase. โDue to some disagreementsโsome recent; some tolerated for close to 2 decadesโwith how collaboration should work, weโve decided that the best course of action was to fork the project,โ developer Nash Muhandes wrote on the DoomWorld forums Wednesday . โI donโt want to see the GZDoom legacy die, as do most all of us, hence why I think the best thing to do is tโฆ

title: OpenAI thinks Elon Musk funded its biggest criticsโwho also hate Musk
summary: โCutthroatโ OpenAI accused of exploiting Musk fight to intimidate and silence critics.
body: Over the past week, OpenAI has faced backlash over subpoenas it sent to nonprofits accused of conspiring with Elon Musk to amplify public criticism of OpenAI as it sought to shift from a nonprofit to for-profit structure. The subpoenas are supposed to support OpenAIโs defense in a lawsuit Muskโs X Corp filed to block the for-profit transition. Seeking a โwide variety of documentsโโincluding a sweeping request for all communications regarding Musk and all information on nonprofitsโ funders and donationsโOpenAI claimed that the subpoenas are intended to probe if Musk was involved in the actions or paid nonprofits to make critical comments, NBC News wrote in a report exhaustively documenting the controversy. But nonprofits have alleged itโs obvious that OpenAI is using the lawsuit to harass, silence, and intimidate its criticsโmost glaringly when it comes to targeting nonprofits that are even more publicly critical of Muskโs companies than they are of OpenAI. title: SpaceX has plans to launch Falcon Heavy from Californiaโif anyone wants it to
summary: There's no big rush to bring SpaceX's Falcon Heavy to Vandenberg Space Force Base.
body: The Department of the Air Force has approved SpaceXโs plans to launch up to 100 missions per year from Vandenberg Space Force Base in California. This would continue the tectonic turnaround at the spaceport on Californiaโs Central Coast. Five years ago, Vandenberg hosted just a single orbital launch. This yearโs number stands at 51 orbital flights, or 53 launches if you count a pair of Minuteman missile tests, the most in a single calendar year at Vandenberg since the early 1970s. Vandenberg is used for missions launching into polar orbits, paths oriented north-south that, over time, cover most of the Earthโs surface area. These orbits are popular for Earth observation satellites. Read full article Comments

title: Antarctica is starting to look a lot like Greenlandโand that isnโt good
summary: Global warming is awakening sleeping giants of ice at the South Pole.
body: As recently as the 1990s, when the Greenland Ice Sheet and the rest of the Arctic region were measurably thawing under the climatic blowtorch of human-caused global warming, most of Antarcticaโs vast ice cap still seemed securely frozen. But not anymore. Physics is physics. As the planet heats up, more ice will melt at both poles, and recent research shows that Antarcticaโs ice caps, glaciers, and floating ice shelves, as well as its sea ice, are just as vulnerable to warming as the Arctic. Both satellite data and field observations in Antarctica reveal alarming signs of a Greenland-like meltdown, with increased surface melting of the ice fields, faster-moving glaciers, and dwindling sea ice. Some scientists are sounding the alarm, warning that the rapid โGreenlandificationโ of Antarctica will have serious consequences, including an accelerated rise in sea levels and significant shifts in rainfall and drought patterns. title: Rice weevil on a grain of rice wins 2025 Nikon Small World contest
summary: Nikon Small World photomicrography contest is an annual reminder that science can be beautiful as well as informative.
body: A stunning image of a rice weevil on a single grain of rice has won the 2025 Nikon Small World photomicrography contest, yielding valuable insight into the structure and behavior ofโand providing a fresh perspective onโthis well-known agricultural pest. The image was taken by Zhang You of Yunnan, China. Another of Youโs photographs placed 15th in this yearโs contest. โIt pays to dive deep into entomology: understanding insectsโ behaviors and mastering lighting,โ You said in a statement. โA standout work blends artistry with scientific rigor, capturing the very essence, energy, and spirit of these creatures.โ There was an element of luck in creating his winning image, too. โI had observed rice weevils in grains before, but never one with its wings spread,โ You said. โThis one was naturally preserved on a windowsill, perhaps in a final attempt to escape. Its tiny size makes manually preparing spread-wing specimens extremely difficult, so encountering it was both serendipitous and inspiring.โ Read full article Comments

body: The Orion spacecraft and Space Launch System rocket have been attached at the hip for the better part of two decades. The big rocket lifts, the smaller spacecraft flies, and Congress keeps the money rolling in. But now there are signs that the twain may, in the not too distant future, split. This is because Lockheed Martin has begun to pivot toward a future in which the Orion spacecraftโthanks to increasing reusability, a focus on cost, and openness to flying on different rocketsโfits into commercial space applications. In interviews, company officials said that if NASA wanted to buy Orion missions as a โservice,โ rather than owning and operating the spacecraft, they were ready to work with the space agency. title: Thousands of customers imperiled after nation-state ransacks F5โs network
summary: Risks to BIG-IP users include supply-chain attacks, credential loss, and vulnerability exploits.
body: Thousands of networksโmany of them operated by the US government and Fortune 500 companiesโface an โimminent threatโ of being breached by a nation-state hacking group following the breach of a major maker of software, the federal government warned Wednesday. F5, a Seattle-based maker of networking software, disclosed the breach on Wednesday. F5 said a โsophisticatedโ threat group working for an undisclosed nation-state government had surreptitiously and persistently dwelled in its network over a โlong-term.โ Security researchers who have responded to similar intrusions in the past took the language to mean the hackers were inside the F5 network for years . Unprecedented During that time, F5 said, the hackers took control of the network segment the company uses to create and distribute updates for BIG IP, a line of server appliances that F5 says is used by 48 of the worldโs top 50 corporations. Wednesdayโs disclosure went on to say the threat group downloaded proprietary BIG-IP source code information about vulnerabilities that had been privately discovered but not yet patched. title: CDC tormented: HR workers summoned from furlough to lay off themselves, others
summary: Traumatized CDC has lost 33% of its workforce this year, union says.
body: The dust is still settling at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention after a mass layoff on Friday, which former employees at the beleaguered agency are describing as a massacre. In separate press briefings on Tuesday, a network of terminated CDC staff that goes by the name the National Public Health Coalition, and the union representing employees at the agency discussed what the wide-scale cuts mean for the American people, as well as the trauma, despair, and damage they have wreaked on the workers of the once-premier public health agency. In a normal federal layoffโcalled a reduction in force, or RIFโthe agency would be given a full outline of the roles and branches or divisions affected, as well as some explanation for the cuts, such as alleged fraud, abuse, or redundancy. However, the Trump administration has provided no such information or explanation, leaving current and former employees to essentially crowdsource what has been lost and only guess at the possible reasons. title: Anthropicโs Claude Haiku 4.5 matches Mayโs frontier model at fraction of cost
summary: Tiny, fast model hits coding scores similar to GPT-5 and Sonnet 4.
body: On Wednesday, Anthropic released Claude Haiku 4.5, a small AI language model that reportedly delivers performance similar to what its frontier model Claude Sonnet 4 achieved five months ago but at one-third the cost and more than twice the speed. The new model is available now to all Claude app, web, and API users. If the benchmarks for Haiku 4.5 reported by Anthropic hold up to independent testing, the fact that the company can match some capabilities of its cutting-edge coding model from only five months ago (and GPT-5 in coding) while providing a dramatic speed increase and cost cut is notable. As a recap, Anthropic ships the Claude family in three model sizes: Haiku (small), Sonnet (medium), and Opus (large). The larger models are based on larger neural networks and typically include deeper contextual knowledge but are slower and more expensive to run. Due to a technique called distillation , companies like Anthropic have been able to craft smaller AI models that match the capability of larger, older models at functional tasks like coding, although it typically comes at the cost of omitting stored knowledge. body: Rejecting opposition from the cable and real estate industries, California Gov. Gavin Newsom signed a bill that aims to increase broadband competition in apartment buildings. The new law taking effect on January 1 says landlords must let tenants โopt out of paying for any subscription from a third-party Internet service provider, such as through a bulk-billing arrangement, to provide service for wired Internet, cellular, or satellite service that is offered in connection with the tenancy.โ It was approved by the state Assembly in a 75โ0 vote in April, and by the Senate in a 30โ7 vote last month. โThis is kind of like a first step in trying to give this industry an opportunity to just treat people fairly,โ Assemblymember Rhodesia Ransom, a Democratic lawmaker who authored the bill, told Ars last month . โItโs not super restrictive. We are not banning bulk billing. Weโre not even limiting how much money the people can make.
